summary: actin polymerization is an evolutionarily conserved biological process in eukaryotic cells. key elements of cellular actin polymerization machinery include, but are not limited to, actin, nucleation promoting factors (NPFs) and the actin-related protein 2/3 complex (Arp2/3) alphabaculovirus is thus far the smallest pathogen known to profit from the host actin polymerization machinery for their propagation. cellular Arp2/3 is activated by P78/83, a virus-encoded NPF [23], which induces cytoplasmic actin polymerization to propel nucleocapsid migration towards the nucleus. the unique feature of nuclear actin polymerization induced by AcMNPV requires the accumulation of the cytoplasm Arp2/3 subcellular distribution is controlled by CRM1-dependent nuclear export under steady-state and virus-infection conditions. this is the first study describing the nuclear retention mechanism of Arp2/3 under steady-state and virus-infection conditions. we prepared plasmid-based expression constructs encoding P40 tagged with a V5 epitope (P40-V5) at its C-terminus or P40 fused to enhanced green fluorescent protein at its N-terminus (EGFP-P40) to monitor the Arp2/3 dynamics during AcMNPV infection. some nuclear localization was observed for cells infected with AcMNPV carrying an EGFP marker. at 24 hpi, the cells were either mock-infected or infected with vAcegfp (MOI = 2). for immunofluorescence microscopy, the cells were fixed, probed with anti-V5 antibody to detect P40-V5. for the cell fractionation assay, the cells were harvested and separated into nuclear (N) and cytoplasmic (C) fractions. the immunoprecipitated proteins and the WCL were separated by SDS-PAGE and probed with anti-Ha and anti-EGFP. they were either mock infected or infected with vAcegfp (MOI = 2). the cells were fixed at 6, 12 and 24 hpi or harvested for fractionation. EGFP-P40 can be used to monitor Arp2/3 dynamics during AcMNPV infection. tagged with mCherry (mC-Ac34) was shown to accumulate EGFP-P40 or P40-V5 in the nucleus when co-expressed in S1. mCherry or mCherry-tagged Ac34 (mC-Ac34) were transiently co-expressed. at 48 hpt, the cells were subjected to fluorescence microscopy assays. immunofluorescence microscopy at 48 hours post-transfection (hpt) showed that exogenous P40 (P40-V5) resided in the cytoplasm of vAc34KOegfp-transfected cells. the restoration of ac34 to vAc34KOegfp (vAc34KOac34, diagramed in S1B Fig) could accumulate P40-V5 in the nucleus. the aa 195–215 region plays a major role in determining the presence of Ac34 in the nucleus. this phenotype indicated that the aa 195–215 region plays a major role in determining the presence of Ac34. Ac34 is responsible for P40 nuclear accumulation induced by AcMNPV. aa 195–215 region is essential for Ac34 to accumulate Arp2/3 in the nucleus. Ac34 is responsible for P40 nuclear accumulation induced by AcMNPV. Sf9 cells were transfected with the indicated bacmids. at 48 hpt, the cells were stained with Alexa Fluor 568-phalloidin. each experiment involves the quantification of 30 transfected cells for each bacmid. cellular CRM1 was knocked down using double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) targeting the 1–1000 nt (ds-crm11-1000) or the 1001–2000 nt (ds-crm11001-2000) of CRM1 mRNA. Western blot assay demonstrated that both dsRNAs significantly down-regulated the endogenous CRM1 level. at 44 hpt, the carrier solvent ethanol (1 l) or an equivalent amount of ethanol containing LMB (0.1 g/ml) were added to the culture medium. at 48 hpt, the cells were fixed and subjected to immunofluorescence microscopy using anti-V5. AcMNPV infection inhibits cellular CRM1-dependent nuclear export. mCherry-NES was transiently expressed in Sf9 cells. mCherry-NES was transiently expressed in Sf9 cells. the bars represent the means and standard errors of the means for three independent experiments. each experiment involves the quantification of 30 transfected cells. each experiment involves the quantification of 30 transfected cells. Ac34 is sufficient to inhibit CRM1-dependent nuclear export. EGFP-NES was co-expressed with mCherry, mC-Ac34, or mC-Ac341-195 in Sf9 cells. at 48 hpt, all the cells were fixed and subjected to fluorescence microscopy assays. mCherry-NES resided in the cytoplasm in vAc34koegfp-transfected cells. the restoration of ac34 (vAc34koac34195–215) could accumulate mCherry-NES in the nucleus. Ac34 induces Arp2/3 nuclear retention by inhibiting CRM1-dependent nuclear export during AcMNPV infection. plasmid-based expression constructs encoding P40 tagged with a V5 epitope (P40-V5) at its C-terminus or P40 fused to enhanced green fluorescent protein at its N-terminus (EGFP-P40) were prepared to monitor the Arp2/3 dynamics during AcMNPV infection. at 24 hpi, the cells were either mock-infected or infected with vAcpolh (MOI = 2). for immunofluorescence microscopy, the cells were fixed, probed with anti-V5 antibody to detect P40-V5, and visualized with Alexa Fluor 568-conjugated secondary antibody (red) the cells were harvested and separated into nuclear (N) and cytoplasmic (C) fractions. proteins and the WCL were separated by SDS-PAGE and probed with anti-Ha and anti-EGFP. phenotypes demonstrated that either the C-terminally tagged P40-V5 or the N-terminally tagged P40-V5 do not impair the incorporation of P40 into Arp2/3. Ac34 inhibits CRM1-dependent nuclear export during AcMNPV infection. EGFP-NES was co-expressed with mCherry, mC-Ac34, or mC-Ac341-195 in Sf9 cells. at 48 hpt, all cells were fixed and subjected to fluorescence microscopy assays. fluorescence microscopy showed that mCherry-NES resided in the cytoplasm in vAc34koegfp-transfected cells. the restoration of ac34 (vAc34koac34), but not ac34 195–215 (vAc34koac34195–215), could accumulate mCherry-NES in the nucleus. the nucleo-cytoplasmic shuttling mechanism other viruses employ a variety of methods to interfere with nucleo-cytoplasmic shuttling of cellular proteins, thus facilitating viral replication and escape from the host anti-viral immune response. most AcMNPV replication processes, including viral genome replication, gene transcription, and nucleocapsid assembly, occur in the nucleus. the inhibition of CRM1-dependent nuclear export by Ac34 could play a key role in the AcMNPV-induced nuclear accumulation of proteins. if Ac34 influences other exportins or these exportins also contribute to the virus-induced protein nuclear accumulation remain to be explored. alphabaculoviruses and betabaculoviruses behave in significantly different ways. late in infection, P78/83 and Arp2/3 accumulate in the nucleus and induce nuclear actin polymerization that converts G-actin to F-actin. the resulting nuclear G-actin pool depletion could lead to the loss of the transcriptional activity of host RNA polymerases. cytochalasin D, a chemical that specifically prevents actin polymerization, behaves as an antagonist of the virus-induced shutdown of host gene expression. perda were cultured in Grace’s medium (Invitrogen) with 5% fetal bovine serum (Invitrogen) and 0.1% Antibiotic-Antimycotic (Invitrogen) at 27°C. the cells were incubated with virus stock solution for 1 h at a multiplicity of infection (MOI) of 2.
